qas.question: Why isn't the southwest Spanish speaking?

answers.text: Through the force of sheer numbers, the English-speaking American settlers entering the Southwest established their language, culture, and law

qas.question: Why didn't California officially become  bilingual?

answers.text: the convention's English-speaking participants felt that the state's remaining minority of Spanish-speakers should simply learn English
the convention ultimately voted 46-39 to revise the earlier clause so that all official proceedings would henceforth be published only in English.

plausible_answers.text: Through the force of sheer numbers, the English-speaking American settlers entering the Southwest established their language, culture, and law
the convention's English-speaking participants felt that the state's remaining minority of Spanish-speakers should simply learn English

qas.question: Why didn't Caifornia officially become monolingual?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Through the force of sheer numbers, the English-speaking American settlers entering the Southwest established their language, culture, and law<b5_0/><a0_0/> as dominant, to the extent it fully displaced Spanish in the public sphere; this is why the <a1_0>United States never developed bilingualism as <b9_0>Canada<b9_0/> did.<a1_0/> For example, the <a2_0><b8_0>California constitutional convention of 1849<b8_0/> had eight Californio participants; the resulting state constitution was produced in English and Spanish,<a2_0/> and it contained a clause requiring all published laws and regulations to be published in both languages. <b7_0>The constitutional convention of 1872<b7_0/> had no Spanish-speaking participants; <a3_0><b6_0>the convention's English-speaking participants felt that the state's remaining minority of Spanish-speakers should simply learn English<b6_0/><a3_0/>; and <a4_0>the convention ultimately voted 46-39 to revise the earlier clause so that all official proceedings would henceforth be published only in English.
